second change we've made is simplified the retrieval pricing so instead of the peak pricing that we had for retrieving
archive tapes you now have a flat one Giga bits one one cent per gigabyte of
data transferred and the third big change we've made in our pricing structure this week is we are changing
from a flat for month $125 gateway fee to a usage based fee so now you pay one
cent for every gigabyte of data that's transferred from the Gateway to AWS and
that's capped at 125 so if you send anything less than 12 terabytes of data

does is it stores it locally in the cache as I mentioned earlier we provide a write back cache so we do synchronous
writes into the cache response your applications you say yep we've got that
data it's stored we also do aggregation within the cache so for example if you do overwrites at the same part of a file
or overwrites of the same blocks of a block device we aggregate that out if
the cache becomes full we use an LRU policy to evict data so they know your coldest data gets evicted from the cache
know to make space for the newer data the hotter data that's being written and
then we take that data that's on the in the cache and we upload it to AWS whether you're
doing files to objects in the file case or you're doing a block device we upload that data into s3 to make sure it gets
durably stored in that instance we're doing as much as we can to try and move a small amount of data as possible some
of that aggregation that we do in the cache helps with that up into AWS to make it durable we do parallel uploads
we play some other tricks on the upload side in order to move that data as quickly as we can as you mentioned here
